title: Albemarle County, Virginia
text:
PopulationRace & EthnicityIncome



Population Trends and Age Dynamics
Population Density (Hex Grid), 2024









Figure Notes: Map uses a hexagonal grid to show population counts within each cell. Population is represented on a log scale, with blue-purple hexagons indicating fewer people and red-yellow hexagons indicating more. Legend is restricted to the 2nd–98th percentiles. Data source: Gridded EIF.


Where People Live
In 2024, Albemarle County was home to 107,686 people. In the map above, darker blue areas indicate less populated regions. Warmer colors indicate more populated areas.
The region had a population density of 58 people per square kilometer, which is more dense than the national average of 37 per square kilometer.


Population Trends
The population grew by 39,170 people between 2000 and 2024, with an average annual growth rate of 1.9%. This is faster than the national average growth rate of 0.8%.
From 2000-2010, the population grew at an average annual rate of 2.53%. From 2010-2020, it grew at a rate of 1.62% annually. And from 2020-2024, it grew by 1.05% annually.
Population Growth, 2000-2024









Figure Notes: Line chart shows annual population from 2000 to 2024. Population is shown on the vertical axis; year is on the horizontal axis. Data source: Gridded EIF.


Age Dynamics
In 2024, 19% of the Albemarle County population was under 18, a lower share than the US. The under-18 population was declining.
In 2024, 58% of the Albemarle County population was aged 19-65, a lower share than the US. The 19-65 population was declining.
In 2024, 21% of the Albemarle County population was over 65, a higher share than the US. The over-65 population was growing.
Population Age Shares, 2000-2024









Figure Notes: Line chart shows the share of the population in three age groups—under 18, ages 19–65, and over 65—for each year from 2000 to 2024. The vertical axis shows population share as a percentage. Data source: Gridded EIF.




Local and National Trends in Racial and Ethnic Population Size and Share (2000-2024)








Notes: The trend lines show how the population has changed over time within Albemarle County. An upward-sloping line indicates population growth.


Comparison of 2024 Racial Shares
Individuals are characterized as Hispanic, Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, Non-Hispanic Asian, and Non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN). A residual category is constructed containing all Non-Hispanic Other, but is not reported separately in the statistics.

White individuals made up 71.9% of the Albemarle County population, compared to 55.0% nationwide.
Black individuals made up 8.2% of the Albemarle County population, compared to 11.6% nationwide.
Hispanic individuals made up 4.5% of the Albemarle County population, compared to 15.8% nationwide.
Asian individuals made up 3% of the Albemarle County population, compared to 4.1% nationwide.
American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) individuals made up 0.2% of the Albemarle County population, compared to 0.8% nationwide.



Population Maps by Race and Ethnicity (2024)
Spatial Distribution of White Population, 2024 
Spatial Distribution of Black Population, 2024 
Spatial Distribution of Hispanic Population, 2024 
Spatial Distribution of Asian Population, 2024 
Spatial Distribution of AIAN Population, 2024 
Figure Notes: Red-yellow hexagons represent higher concentrations of each racial group and blue-purple hexagons represent lower concentrations. The scales vary to reflect differences in overall population levels across groups.




Income Trends and Shares
The average household income in 2024 was 213,759 dollars. The average annual growth rate was 1.3% compared with the US annual growth rate of 3.7%.
Albemarle County Income Decile Distribution, 2024









Figure Notes: The figure shows the share of the Albemarle County population within each decile of the national income distribution.


Income Deciles and AGI
Income deciles divide the national population into ten equally sized income bins. The first decile reflects the 10% of the US population with the lowest income, while the 10th decile reflects the 10% of the population with the highest income.
Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) is defined as the total gross income per household minus specific adjustments.
Annual AGI Growth, 2000-2024








Table Notes: The table shows the average income level for each decile group in 2024. The annual growth represents the average annual change in income from 2000 to 2024. Positive values represent an increase in average income while negative values represent a decrease in average income.


Race-Income Trends and Shares
The population with the highest average income was the Asian population and the population with the lowest average income was the Black population. The population with the highest average annual income growth rate from 2000–2024 was the Asian population and the population with the lowest average annual growth rate was the Black population.
Annual Income Growth Rates, By Race/Ethnicity, 2000-2024








Table Notes: The table shows the average household income and the average growth rate over the last 25 years by race. Higher growth rates indicate faster growth over time.
Race-Specific Income Distributions: Albemarle County vs. US, 2024









Figure Notes: The dark blue bars show the share of the population within each decile of the national income distribution for each race in Albemarle County, while the light blue bars show the income decile distributions for every race in the US. The set of figures shows how race-specific income distributions in Albemarle County differ from US race-specific income distributions. Differences between the dark and light blue lines indicate a difference between the Albemarle County and US income distributions for the given decile.





© 2025 Environmental Inequality Lab.
Disclaimer: This content is presented to inform interested parties of research and to encourage discussion. Any opinions and conclusions expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not reflect the views of the U.S. Census Bureau.

title: About
text: The Environmental Inequality Lab is a nonpartisan research group that applies a rigorous, data-driven approach to understand how our environment shapes economic opportunity and well-being.

title: About
text: The Environmental Inequality Lab is a nonpartisan research group that applies a rigorous, data-driven approach to understand how our environment shapes economic opportunity and well-being.

title: About
text:
This Analysis
The Regional Data Explorer provides a detailed view of demographic and economic patterns and trends for counties across the United States using the most detailed publicly available Census data. The analysis provides local leaders, residents, and service providers with data-driven insights to provide context and facilitate planning, resource allocation, and investment.

title: About
text:
The Data Source
The Gridded Environmental Impacts Frame (Gridded EIF) is an innovative, privacy-protected dataset derived from the Census Bureau’s confidential Environmental Impacts Frame (EIF) microdata. Organized on a fixed 0.01° x 0.01° grid (approximately 1 km² × 1 km²), the Gridded EIF provides population counts by age, sex, race and ethnicity, as well as race-specific population counts by household income decile from administrative tax records. This structure enables more spatially precise analysis than traditional place-based data while maintaining strict confidentiality standards.
Estimates reflect the most detailed available data on the local population, though some figures may understate true counts. Please see https://www.census.gov/data/experimental-data-products/gridded-eif.html for more information.

title: About
text:
Contributors
This project was developed by researchers at the Environmental Inequality Lab.

Arnav Dharmagadda (University of Virginia), Elizabeth Shiker (University of Virginia), and Josie Fischman (Bowdoin College) contributed to the preliminary development of the county-level analysis and the preparation of the Gridded Environmental Impacts Frame (Gridded EIF) for county-level applications.

Web design and development of the Regional Data Explorer were led by Elizabeth Shiker.

© 2025 Environmental Inequality Lab.
Disclaimer: This content is presented to inform interested parties of research and to encourage discussion. Any opinions and conclusions expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not reflect the views of the U.S. Census Bureau.

title: Regional Data Explorer
text:
Explore population and income data for every county in the United States.
The Regional Data Explorer provides interactive access to county-level demographic and economic trends using the Gridded Environmental Impacts Frame (Gridded EIF)—an innovative, privacy-protected dataset developed by the Environmental Inequality Lab in collaboration with the U.S. Census Bureau.




Explore by state
Select a state to view detailed county-level data on population, age, race and ethnicity, and household income.
